bestBHT.bht: In this prophetic declaration, it is hinted that those who were initially chosen may lose their high place, while the previously cast-off Gentiles will attain the first rank. This warns the Jews against placing their confidence solely in their chosen status. Instead, it reveals that the Gentiles, who were called last, will be first and share in the glory and happiness of the patriarchs and prophets. Conversely, the Jews, who anticipated the kingdom, may end up rejected and despised, highlighting that rewards are not solely based on order of calling.

Henry Alford: They seem to be a prophetic declaration of what shall be in the course of the ingathering of these guests."
Some who were the it, or among the first to believe, shall fall from their high place, and vice verse."
This former has, as Stier notices, been remarkably the case with the Oriental Churches, which were the first founded and flourishing.
John Calvin: All that he intended here was, to throw down the vain confidence of the Jews, who, having been chosen by God in preference to all the rest of the world, trusted to this distinction, and imagined that God was in a manner bound to them.

For this reason, Christ threatens that their condition will soon be changed; that the Gentiles, who were at that time cast off, would obtain the first rank; and that the Jews, deprived of their honor, would not even occupy the farthest corner in the Church.
Will not hold even the lowest rank, or some small corner in the Church.
Philip Schaff: Here the saying seems to be applied to the ingathering of the guests, just spoken of; not simply to the Jews and Gentiles as such, but to individuals and churches and nations all through the ingathering."
For example: the church at Jerusalem and her Gentile off-shoots, the Oriental churches.
Archibald T. Robertson: Last (εσχατο). This saying was repeated many times (Matthew 19:30; Mark 10:31; Matthew 20:16).
John Gill: The Gentiles, the most mean and abject, afar from God, aliens from the commonwealth of Israel, called last of all; these shall be first, and sit down among patriarchs and prophets, men of the first rank here on earth, in the kingdom of heaven, and enjoy the same glory and happiness with them.

The Jews, who were first the visible professing people of God, to whom the oracles of God, and outward privileges and ordinances were given; who had the Messiah first sent to them, and the Gospel first preached among them; these shall be last, be rejected and despised, and shut out of the kingdom of heaven, they thought themselves heirs of, and expected to enjoy.
And behold, there are last which shall be first, and there are first which shall be last.
John Wesley: Many of the Gentiles who were latest called, shall be most highly rewarded.
Many of the Jews who were first called, shall have no reward at all.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, there is a prophetic declaration about the course of the ingathering of the guests. It suggests that some who were among the first to believe may fall from their high place, while others who were initially cast off, like the Gentiles, will obtain the first rank. This reversal of positions is a warning to the Jews, who had placed their confidence in their chosen status. It signifies that the Gentiles, who were called last, will be first and will sit among the patriarchs and prophets, sharing in the same glory and happiness. On the other hand, the Jews, who were first called and expected to enjoy the kingdom of heaven, may end up being last, rejected and despised. This reversal of fortunes serves as a reminder that rewards are not solely based on order of calling, and that many of the Gentiles, who were the latest called, shall be highly rewarded.

In this prophetic declaration, it is hinted that those who were initially chosen may lose their high place, while the previously cast-off Gentiles will attain the first rank. This warns the Jews against placing their confidence solely in their chosen status. Instead, it reveals that the Gentiles, who were called last, will be first and share in the glory and happiness of the patriarchs and prophets. Conversely, the Jews, who anticipated the kingdom, may end up rejected and despised, highlighting that rewards are not solely based on order of calling.

The prophetic declaration in this passage suggests a reversal of positions in the ingathering of guests. Those who were among the first to believe may fall from their high place, while the previously cast-off Gentiles will obtain the first rank. This warning cautions against placing confidence solely in chosen status. The Gentiles, called last, will be first and share in the glory and happiness of the patriarchs and prophets, while the Jews, who expected the kingdom, may end up rejected and despised. Rewards are not solely based on order of calling.

This prophetic declaration warns that some who were among the first to believe may fall from their high place, while the previously rejected Gentiles will obtain the first rank. It cautions against placing confidence solely in chosen status. The Gentiles, called last, will share in the glory of the patriarchs and prophets, while the Jews, who expected the kingdom, may end up rejected. Rewards are not solely based on order of calling, as many of the Gentiles will be highly rewarded.

This prophetic declaration warns of a reversal in the ingathering of guests. Some initially chosen may fall, while previously cast-off Gentiles will rise to the first rank. It cautions against misplaced confidence in chosen status. The Gentiles will join the patriarchs and prophets in sharing glory and happiness, while the Jews may end up rejected and despised. Rewards are not solely based on order of calling; many Gentiles will be highly rewarded, and some Jews may receive no reward at all.
